comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment:
This is not our standard way to mock. Makes this too much confusing.
remove the Set and the filling of the set from the expectations and in this kind of block, please use only: mock.doSomething() result=

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: I have corrected the issue

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment:
There's already a pattern for adding attribute values to an entity. These should be <AttributeName>_ATTRIBUTE.
Look at LeaveRequest entity for an example.

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: The comments has been incorporated

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment:
Why are we adding all these attributes? At the moment we are just showing zero values because we're never setting these values.
The Applicability feature is not planed for the forseeable future but I dont belieave that these attributes should exist in this entity.
If we need to show default values somewhere, why not just hard code them wherever they are needed instead of adding them to the entity?

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: This was agreed with Gareth that we would put the placeholder fields for availability calculation

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: Why Long and not long? We need the Long object?

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: Since it is an entity object and a POJO, I thought it is better to have a object rather than primitive type.Hence the long object

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: This is more than 100%

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: This column widths are changed so that the total column width is 100%. As such the framework will not give pose any problem but changed it to keep with consistent with other list views

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: Why Long and not long? Do we need the Long object?

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: Since it is an entity object and a POJO, I thought it is better to have a object rather than primitive type.Hence the long object

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: I don't agree. This is an unnecessary overhead in memory. If you're not needing an object, to represent null values, or anything that you might really need, then you should always use the primitive type. This is an immutable value and so much more safe to use than an Object.

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: I have incorporated the above said changes

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: We still dont have an implementation for this. For this reason why are we adding extra fields to the entity now?

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: We still dont have an implementation for this. For this reason why are we adding extra fields to the entity now?

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: Same as above

reviewTimeLines.summary: FAB-1745: View History of the Selected Leave Plan Adjudication

comments.author: Jose Martinez
comments.comment: Shouldn't we return a List<AdjucicationChange> instead of Rel<AdjucicationChange>?

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: The AdjucicationChange extends OCObjectChange class. If we return List<AdjucicationChange>, then framework is not returning the associated entities. Hence we are using Rel<AdjucicationChange>

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: The above method has been removed. We are using public List<AdjudicationChange> getAdjudicationChangeList() to fetch the list of AdjucicationChange entities.

comments.author: John McCosker
comments.comment: Why is there an empty string being appended

comments.author: Mohan Pattabhiramaswamy
comments.comment: Empty string is being appended to bring about uniformity in the alignment when it gets displayed in list view. If we return Long, then the list view is rendering the values in a right aligned manner. If we make it as string the elements are alinged left

comments.comment:
Would it be possible to create a JIRA to refactor this method at some stage in the future.
I'm finding it very hard to follow it - there could be a lot more methods within but in fairness that would also involve refactoring other tests, so a bit of work involved.
